title: Ireland finally loses patience with EU over bailout 'surveillance' | World | News | Express.co.uk
text:
‘Clear off!’ Ireland finally loses patience with EU over ‘excessive surveillance’ ‘Clear off!’ Ireland finally loses patience with EU over ‘excessive surveillance’ THE EUROPEAN Union has been told to clear off by an Irish MEP who has lost patience with Eurocrat interference. PUBLISHED: PUBLISHED: 13:00, Sat, Feb 11, 2017 GETTY Brian Hayes has lashed out at the EU for its bailout 'surveillance' 
Brian Hayes has accused the Commission of “excessive surveillance” due to its bi-annual visits by ministers to inspect the Republic of Ireland’s finances. 
These six-monthly “missions” ensure the country continues to repay bailout funds - but Mr Hayes believes this is a waste of resources considering Ireland’s now-booming economy. 
With European Union visits planned every six months until 2031, the MEP believes the EU should put its efforts towards a more worthwhile cause - such as preparing for Brexit. Related articles Brexit may be BLOCKED by Article 50 referendum in Republic of Ireland 
Brian Hayes said: “The current post-bailout procedure for Ireland represents an excessive level of surveillance. For a country with the highest growth in the EU, it seems perverse that we have twice yearly reports assessing our economic and financial situation, along with regular missions. FACEBOOK / BRIAN HAYES Brian Hayes outside 10 Downing Street during an EU visit 
“Would it not be better for the Commission to focus on preparing for the challenge of Brexit than to continue with these superfluous bailout visits which seem to just represent a box-ticking exercise.” 
Mr Hayes, who represents Dublin in the European Parliament, said the Commission’s visits were an example of the bloc’s inflexibility.
